an5.213:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.

an5.213:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, dussīlo sīlavipanno pamādādhikaraṇaṃ mahatiṃ bhogajāniṃ nigacchati.
an5.213:1.3.eng: Firstly, an unethical person loses great wealth on account of negligence.

an5.213:1.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo ādīnavo dussīlassa sīlavipattiyā.

an5.213:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, dussīlassa sīlavipannassa pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati.
an5.213:2.1.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person gets a bad reputation.

an5.213:2.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo ādīnavo dussīlassa sīlavipattiyā.

an5.213:3.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, dussīlo sīlavipanno yaññadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamati—yadi khattiyaparisaṃ, yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ, yadi gahapatiparisaṃ, yadi samaṇaparisaṃ—avisārado upasaṅkamati maṅkubhūto.
an5.213:3.1.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person enters any kind of assembly timid and embarrassed, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.

an5.213:3.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, tatiyo ādīnavo dussīlassa sīlavipattiyā.

an5.213:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, dussīlo sīlavipanno sammūḷho kālaṃ karoti.
an5.213:4.1.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person feels lost when they die.

an5.213:4.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho ādīnavo dussīlassa sīlavipattiyā.

an5.213:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, dussīlo sīlavipanno kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an5.213:5.1.eng: Furthermore, an unethical person, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an5.213:5.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamo ādīnavo dussīlassa sīlavipattiyā.

an5.213:5.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā dussīlassa sīlavipattiyā.
an5.213:5.3.eng: These are the five drawbacks for an unethical person because of their failure in ethics.

an5.213:6.1.eng: There are these five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.

an5.213:6.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, sīlavā sīlasampanno appamādādhikaraṇaṃ mahantaṃ bhogakkhandhaṃ adhigacchati.
an5.213:6.3.eng: Firstly, an ethical person gains great wealth on account of diligence.

an5.213:6.4.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭhamo ānisaṃso sīlavato sīlasampadāya.

an5.213:7.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sīlavato sīlasampannassa kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchati.
an5.213:7.1.eng: Furthermore, an ethical person gets a good reputation.

an5.213:7.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, dutiyo ānisaṃso sīlavato sīlasampadāya.

an5.213:8.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sīlavā sīlasampanno yaññadeva parisaṃ upasaṅkamati—yadi khattiyaparisaṃ, yadi brāhmaṇaparisaṃ, yadi gahapatiparisaṃ, yadi samaṇaparisaṃ—visārado upasaṅkamati amaṅkubhūto.
an5.213:8.1.eng: Furthermore, an ethical person enters any kind of assembly bold and self-assured, whether it’s an assembly of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics.

an5.213:8.2.pli: Ayaṃ bhikkhave, tatiyo ānisaṃso sīlavato sīlasampadāya.

an5.213:9.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sīlavā sīlasampanno asammūḷho kālaṃ karoti.
an5.213:9.1.eng: Furthermore, an ethical person dies not feeling lost.

an5.213:9.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, catuttho ānisaṃso sīlavato sīlasampadāya.

an5.213:10.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, sīlavā sīlasampanno kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an5.213:10.1.eng: Furthermore, when an ethical person’s body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.213:10.2.pli: Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, pañcamo ānisaṃso sīlavato sīlasampadāya.

an5.213:10.3.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā sīlavato sīlasampadāyā”ti.
an5.213:10.3.eng: These are the five benefits for an ethical person because of their accomplishment in ethics.”

an5.214:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks for an individual who talks a lot.

an5.214:1.3.pli: Musā bhaṇati, pisuṇaṃ bhaṇati, pharusaṃ bhaṇati, samphappalāpaṃ bhaṇati, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an5.214:1.3.eng: They use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, and nonsensical. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an5.214:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā bahubhāṇismiṃ puggale.
an5.214:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks for an individual who talks a lot.

an5.214:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits for an individual who talks thoughtfully.

an5.214:2.3.pli: Na musā bhaṇati, na pisuṇaṃ bhaṇati, na pharusaṃ bhaṇati, na samphappalāpaṃ bhaṇati, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an5.214:2.3.eng: They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, and nonsensical. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.214:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā mantabhāṇismiṃ puggale”ti.
an5.214:2.4.eng: These are the five benefits for an individual who talks thoughtfully.”

an5.215:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of intolerance.

an5.215:1.3.pli: Bahuno janassa appiyo hoti amanāpo, verabahulo ca hoti, vajjabahulo ca, sammūḷho kālaṃ karoti, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an5.215:1.3.eng: Most people find you unlikable and disagreeable. You have lots of enmity and many faults. You feel lost when you die. And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an5.215:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā akkhantiyā.
an5.215:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks to intolerance.

an5.215:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of tolerance.

an5.215:2.3.pli: Bahuno janassa piyo hoti manāpo, na verabahulo hoti, na vajjabahulo, asammūḷho kālaṃ karoti, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an5.215:2.3.eng: Most people find you dear and agreeable. You have little enmity and few faults. You don’t feel lost when you die. And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.215:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā khantiyā”ti.
an5.215:2.4.eng: These are the five benefits of tolerance.”

an5.216:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of intolerance.

an5.216:1.3.pli: Bahuno janassa appiyo hoti amanāpo, luddo ca hoti, vippaṭisārī ca, sammūḷho kālaṃ karoti, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an5.216:1.3.eng: Most people find you unlikable and disagreeable. You’re cruel and remorseful. You feel lost when you die. And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an5.216:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā akkhantiyā.
an5.216:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks to intolerance.

an5.216:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of tolerance.

an5.216:2.3.pli: Bahuno janassa piyo hoti manāpo, aluddo ca hoti, avippaṭisārī ca, asammūḷho kālaṃ karoti, kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an5.216:2.3.eng: Most people find you likable and agreeable. You’re neither cruel nor remorseful. You don’t feel lost when you die. And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.216:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā khantiyā”ti.
an5.216:2.4.eng: These are the five benefits of tolerance.”

an5.217:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of unimpressive conduct.

an5.217:1.4.eng: After examination, sensible people criticize you.

an5.217:1.6.eng: You feel lost when you die.

an5.217:1.7.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
an5.217:1.7.eng: And when your body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

an5.217:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā apāsādike.
an5.217:1.8.eng: These are the five drawbacks of unimpressive conduct.

an5.217:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of impressive conduct.

an5.217:2.4.eng: After examination, sensible people praise you.

an5.217:2.6.eng: You don’t feel lost when you die.

an5.217:2.7.pli: kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā sugatiṃ saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati.
an5.217:2.7.eng: And when the body breaks up, after death, you’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.

an5.217:2.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā pāsādike”ti.
an5.217:2.8.eng: These are the five benefits of impressive conduct.”

an5.218:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of unimpressive conduct.

an5.218:1.3.pli: Appasannā nappasīdanti, pasannānañca ekaccānaṃ aññathattaṃ hoti, satthusāsanaṃ akataṃ hoti, pacchimā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati, cittamassa nappasīdati.
an5.218:1.3.eng: You don’t inspire confidence in those without it. You cause some with confidence to change their minds. You don’t follow the Teacher’s instructions. Those who come after you follow your example. And your mind doesn’t become clear.

an5.218:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā apāsādike.
an5.218:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks of unimpressive conduct.

an5.218:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of impressive conduct.

an5.218:2.3.pli: Appasannā pasīdanti, pasannānañca bhiyyobhāvo hoti, satthusāsanaṃ kataṃ hoti, pacchimā janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati, cittamassa pasīdati.
an5.218:2.3.eng: You inspire confidence in those without it. You increase confidence in those who have it. You follow the Teacher’s instructions. Those who come after you follow your example. And your mind becomes clear.

an5.218:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā pāsādike”ti.
an5.218:2.4.eng: These are the five benefits of impressive conduct.”

an5.219:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of a fire.

an5.219:1.3.pli: Acakkhusso, dubbaṇṇakaraṇo, dubbalakaraṇo, saṅgaṇikāpavaḍḍhano, tiracchānakathāpavattaniko hoti.
an5.219:1.3.eng: It’s bad for your eyes. It’s bad for your complexion. It makes you weak. It draws in groups. And it encourages low talk.

an5.219:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā aggismin”ti.
an5.219:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks of a fire.”

an5.22:1.1.pli: “So vata, bhikkhave, bhikkhu agāravo appatisso asabhāgavuttiko ‘sabrahmacārīsu ābhisamācārikaṃ dhammaṃ paripūressatī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an5.22:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, it is quite impossible for a disrespectful and irreverent mendicant with incompatible lifestyle to fulfill the practice dealing with supplementary regulations regarding their spiritual companions.

an5.22:1.2.pli: ‘Ābhisamācārikaṃ dhammaṃ aparipūretvā sekhaṃ dhammaṃ paripūressatī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an5.22:1.2.eng: Without fulfilling the practice dealing with supplementary regulations, it’s impossible to fulfill the practice of a trainee.

an5.22:1.3.pli: ‘Sekhaṃ dhammaṃ aparipūretvā sīlakkhandhaṃ paripūressatī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an5.22:1.3.eng: Without fulfilling the practice of a trainee, it’s impossible to fulfill the entire spectrum of ethics.

an5.22:1.4.pli: ‘Sīlakkhandhaṃ aparipūretvā samādhikkhandhaṃ paripūressatī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an5.22:1.4.eng: Without fulfilling the entire spectrum of ethics, it’s impossible to fulfill the entire spectrum of immersion.

an5.22:1.5.pli: ‘Samādhikkhandhaṃ aparipūretvā paññākkhandhaṃ paripūressatī’ti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati.
an5.22:1.5.eng: Without fulfilling the entire spectrum of immersion, it’s impossible to fulfill the entire spectrum of wisdom.

an5.22:2.1.pli: So vata, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sagāravo sappatisso sabhāgavuttiko ‘sabrahmacārīsu ābhisamācārikaṃ dhammaṃ paripūressatī’ti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
an5.22:2.1.eng: But it is quite possible for a respectful and reverent mendicant with compatible lifestyle to fulfill the practice dealing with supplementary regulations regarding their spiritual companions.

an5.22:2.2.pli: ‘Ābhisamācārikaṃ dhammaṃ paripūretvā sekhaṃ dhammaṃ paripūressatī’ti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
an5.22:2.2.eng: Having fulfilled the practice dealing with supplementary regulations, it’s possible to fulfill the practice of a trainee.

an5.22:2.3.pli: ‘Sekhaṃ dhammaṃ paripūretvā sīlakkhandhaṃ paripūressatī’ti ṭhānametaṃ vijjati.
an5.22:2.3.eng: Having fulfilled the practice of a trainee, it’s possible to fulfill the entire spectrum of ethics.

an5.22:2.4.eng: Having fulfilled the entire spectrum of ethics, it’s possible to fulfill the entire spectrum of immersion.

an5.22:2.5.eng: Having fulfilled the entire spectrum of immersion, it’s possible to fulfill the entire spectrum of wisdom.”

an5.220:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of Madhurā.

an5.220:1.3.eng: The ground is uneven and dusty, the hounds are fierce, the native spirits are vicious, and it’s hard to get almsfood.

an5.220:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā madhurāyan”ti.
an5.220:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks of Madhurā.”

an5.221:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, ādīnavā dīghacārikaṃ anavatthacārikaṃ anuyuttassa viharato.
an5.221:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks for someone who likes long and aimless wandering.

an5.221:1.3.pli: Assutaṃ na suṇāti, sutaṃ na pariyodāpeti, sutenekaccena avisārado hoti, gāḷhaṃ rogātaṅkaṃ phusati, na ca mittavā hoti.
an5.221:1.3.eng: You don’t learn new things. You don’t clarify what you’ve learned. You lack confidence in some things you have learned. You contract a severe illness. You don’t have any friends.

an5.221:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā dīghacārikaṃ anavatthacārikaṃ anuyuttassa viharato.
an5.221:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks for someone who likes long and aimless wandering.

an5.221:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of a reasonable amount of wandering.

an5.221:2.3.pli: Assutaṃ suṇāti, sutaṃ pariyodāpeti, sutenekaccena visārado hoti, na gāḷhaṃ rogātaṅkaṃ phusati, mittavā ca hoti.
an5.221:2.3.eng: You learn new things. You clarify what you’ve learned. You have confidence in some things you have learned. You don’t contract severe illness. You have friends.

an5.221:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā samavatthacāre”ti.
an5.221:2.4.eng: These are the five benefits of a reasonable amount of wandering.”

an5.222:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, ādīnavā dīghacārikaṃ anavatthacārikaṃ anuyuttassa viharato.
an5.222:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks for someone who likes long and aimless wandering.

an5.222:1.3.pli: Anadhigataṃ nādhigacchati, adhigatā parihāyati, adhigatenekaccena avisārado hoti, gāḷhaṃ rogātaṅkaṃ phusati, na ca mittavā hoti.
an5.222:1.3.eng: You don’t achieve the unachieved. What you have achieved falls away. You lose confidence in some things you’ve achieved. You contract a severe illness. You don’t have any friends.

an5.222:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā dīghacārikaṃ anavatthacārikaṃ anuyuttassa viharato.
an5.222:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks for someone who likes long and aimless wandering.

an5.222:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of a reasonable amount of wandering.

an5.222:2.3.pli: Anadhigataṃ adhigacchati, adhigatā na parihāyati, adhigatenekaccena visārado hoti, na gāḷhaṃ rogātaṅkaṃ phusati, mittavā ca hoti.
an5.222:2.3.eng: You achieve the unachieved. What you have achieved doesn’t fall away. You’re confident in some things you’ve achieved. You don’t contract severe illness. You have friends.

an5.222:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā samavatthacāre”ti.
an5.222:2.4.eng: These are the five benefits of a reasonable amount of wandering.”

an5.223:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of overstaying.

an5.223:1.3.pli: Bahubhaṇḍo hoti bahubhaṇḍasannicayo, bahubhesajjo hoti bahubhesajjasannicayo, bahukicco hoti bahukaraṇīyo byatto kiṅkaraṇīyesu, saṃsaṭṭho viharati gahaṭṭhapabbajitehi ananulomikena gihisaṃsaggena, tamhā ca āvāsā pakkamanto sāpekkho pakkamati.
an5.223:1.3.eng: You have a lot of stuff and store it up. You have a lot of medicine and store it up. You have a lot of duties and responsibilities, and become capable in whatever needs to be done. You mix closely with laypeople and renunciates, socializing inappropriately like a layperson. And when you leave that monastery, you miss it.

an5.223:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā atinivāse.
an5.223:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks of overstaying.

an5.223:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of staying for a reasonable length of time.

an5.223:2.3.pli: Na bahubhaṇḍo hoti na bahubhaṇḍasannicayo, na bahubhesajjo hoti na bahubhesajjasannicayo, na bahukicco hoti na bahukaraṇīyo na byatto kiṅkaraṇīyesu, asaṃsaṭṭho viharati gahaṭṭhapabbajitehi ananulomikena gihisaṃsaggena, tamhā ca āvāsā pakkamanto anapekkho pakkamati.
an5.223:2.3.eng: You don’t have a lot of stuff and store it up. You don’t have a lot of medicine and store it up. You don’t have a lot of duties and responsibilities, or become capable in whatever needs to be done. You don’t mix closely with laypeople and renunciates, socializing inappropriately like a layperson. And when you leave that monastery, you don’t miss it.

an5.223:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā samavatthavāse”ti.
an5.223:2.4.eng: These are the five benefits of staying for a reasonable length of time.”

an5.224:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of overstaying.

an5.224:1.3.pli: Āvāsamaccharī hoti, kulamaccharī hoti, lābhamaccharī hoti, vaṇṇamaccharī hoti, dhammamaccharī hoti.
an5.224:1.3.eng: You become stingy with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teaching.

an5.224:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā atinivāse.
an5.224:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks of overstaying.

an5.224:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of staying for a reasonable length of time.

an5.224:2.3.pli: Na āvāsamaccharī hoti, na kulamaccharī hoti, na lābhamaccharī hoti, na vaṇṇamaccharī hoti, na dhammamaccharī hoti.
an5.224:2.3.eng: You’re not stingy with dwellings, families, material things, praise, and the teaching.

an5.224:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā samavatthavāse”ti.
an5.224:2.4.eng: These are the five benefits of staying for a reasonable length of time.”

an5.225:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of visiting families.

an5.225:1.3.pli: Anāmantacāre āpajjati, raho nisajjāya āpajjati, paṭicchanne āsane āpajjati, mātugāmassa uttari chappañcavācāhi dhammaṃ desento āpajjati, kāmasaṅkappabahulo viharati.
an5.225:1.3.eng: You fall into an offense for wandering without leave. You fall into an offense for sitting in a private place with someone of the opposite sex. You fall into an offense for sitting in a hidden place with someone of the opposite sex. You fall into an offense for teaching more than five or six sentences to someone of the opposite sex. You have a lot of sensual thoughts.

an5.225:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā kulūpake”ti.
an5.225:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks of visiting families.”

an5.226:1.1.pli: “Pañcime, bhikkhave, ādīnavā kulūpakassa bhikkhuno ativelaṃ kulesu saṃsaṭṭhassa viharato.
an5.226:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks for a mendicant who visits families for too long, mixing closely with them.

an5.226:1.3.eng: You often see members of the opposite sex.

an5.226:1.5.eng: Being so close, you become intimate.

an5.226:1.7.pli: otiṇṇacittassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ: ‘anabhirato vā brahmacariyaṃ carissati aññataraṃ vā saṅkiliṭṭhaṃ āpattiṃ āpajjissati sikkhaṃ vā paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissati’.
an5.226:1.7.eng: When your mind is swamped by lust, you can expect that you will lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, or commit one of the corrupt offenses, or resign the training and return to a lesser life.

an5.226:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā kulūpakassa bhikkhuno ativelaṃ kulesu saṃsaṭṭhassa viharato”ti.
an5.226:1.8.eng: These are the five drawbacks for a mendicant who visits families for too long, mixing closely with them.”

an5.227:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of riches.

an5.227:1.3.pli: Aggisādhāraṇā bhogā, udakasādhāraṇā bhogā, rājasādhāraṇā bhogā, corasādhāraṇā bhogā, appiyehi dāyādehi sādhāraṇā bhogā.
an5.227:1.3.eng: Fire, water, kings, thieves, and unloved heirs all take a share.

an5.227:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā bhogesu.
an5.227:1.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks of riches.

an5.227:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits of riches.

an5.227:2.3.pli: Bhoge nissāya attānaṃ sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati, mātāpitaro sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati, puttadāradāsakammakaraporise sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati, mittāmacce sukheti pīṇeti sammā sukhaṃ pariharati, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhāpeti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.
an5.227:2.3.eng: Riches enable you to make yourself happy and pleased, to make your mother and father; your children, partners, bondservants, workers, and staff, and your friends and colleagues happy and pleased, and to keep them all happy. And they enable you to establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.

an5.227:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā bhogesū”ti.
an5.227:2.4.eng: These are the five benefits of riches.”

an5.228:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks for a family who takes their meals late in the day.

an5.228:1.3.pli: Ye te atithī pāhunā, te na kālena paṭipūjenti;
an5.228:1.3.eng: When guests visit, they are not served on time.

an5.228:1.4.pli: yā tā balipaṭiggāhikā devatā, tā na kālena paṭipūjenti;
an5.228:1.4.eng: The deities who accept spirit-offerings are not served on time.

an5.228:1.5.pli: ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekabhattikā rattūparatā viratā vikālabhojanā, te na kālena paṭipūjenti;
an5.228:1.5.eng: Ascetics and brahmins who eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night, and from food at the wrong time are not served on time.

an5.228:1.6.eng: Bondservants, workers, and staff do their duties neglectfully.

an5.228:1.7.eng: A meal eaten during the wrong period is not nutritious.

an5.228:1.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā ussūrabhatte kule.
an5.228:1.8.eng: These are the five drawbacks for a family who takes their meals late in the day.

an5.228:2.1.eng: There are these five benefits for a family who takes their meals at a proper time.

an5.228:2.3.pli: Ye te atithī pāhunā, te kālena paṭipūjenti;
an5.228:2.3.eng: When guests visit, they are served on time.

an5.228:2.4.pli: yā tā balipaṭiggāhikā devatā, tā kālena paṭipūjenti;
an5.228:2.4.eng: The deities who accept spirit-offerings are served on time.

an5.228:2.5.pli: ye te samaṇabrāhmaṇā ekabhattikā rattūparatā viratā vikālabhojanā, te kālena paṭipūjenti;
an5.228:2.5.eng: Ascetics and brahmins who eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night, and from food at the wrong time are served on time.

an5.228:2.6.eng: Bondservants, workers, and staff do their duties attentively.

an5.228:2.7.eng: A meal eaten during the proper period is nutritious.

an5.228:2.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ānisaṃsā samayabhatte kule”ti.
an5.228:2.8.eng: These are the five benefits for a family who takes their meals at a proper time.”

an5.229:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these five drawbacks of a black snake.

an5.229:1.3.eng: It’s filthy, stinking, cowardly, frightening, and treacherous.

an5.229:1.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā kaṇhasappe.
an5.229:1.4.eng: These are the five dangers of a black snake.

an5.229:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, pañcime ādīnavā mātugāme.
an5.229:2.1.eng: In the same way there are five drawbacks of a lady.

an5.229:2.3.eng: She’s filthy, stinking, cowardly, frightening, and treacherous.

an5.229:2.4.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, pañca ādīnavā mātugāme”ti.
an5.229:2.4.eng: These are the five drawbacks of a lady.”
